Package piece

Class ChessPiece

java.lang.Object
piece.ChessPiece
Direct Known Subclasses:
Bishop, King, Knight, Pawn, Queen, Rook
public abstract class ChessPiece
extends java.lang.Object
This is an abstract class for all chess pieces. The class includes variables for the pieces row, column, and team designation. The class includes the methods getRow, getColumn, and getTeam to get the pieces row, column, and team designation respectively. Additionally, the capture method changes the row and column fields to -1 to denote a piece has been captured. There is a single abstract method named move, which will be defined in each subclass depending on how each piece is able to move on the board.
Author:
Kaushal Patel, John Hoban

  • Constructor Details

    • ChessPiece

      public ChessPiece​(int row, int column, int team)
      Generic constructor that will be called whenever a new piece of any kind is made.
      Parameters:
      row - Starting row/rank.
      column - Starting column/file.
      team - The piece's team. Should be either BLACK or WHITE.

  • Method Details

    • getRow

      public int getRow()
      Returns:
      Returns the row/rank of the piece.

    • getColumn

      public int getColumn()
      Returns:
      Returns the column/file of the piece.

    • getTeam

      public int getTeam()
      Returns:
      Returns which player the piece belongs to.

    • capture

      public void capture()
      This method denotes the piece as being captured by setting its row/rank and column/file both to -1.

    • areValidCoordinates

      public static boolean areValidCoordinates​(int row, int col)
      Checks if a row-column pair falls within the bounds of the chess board.
      Parameters:
      row - Row value of the proposed coordinate.
      col - Column value of the proposed coordinate.
      Returns:
      True if the coordinates fall inside an 8x8 board, false otherwise.

    • move

      public boolean move​(int newColumn, int newRow)
      Method for moving a piece based on a piece's unique way of generating a moveset. IMPORTANT: THIS MUST BE OVERRIDEN FOR PAWN AND KING SINCE THEY HAVE EXTRA PROPERTIES TO CHANGE AFTER A MOVE!
      Parameters:
      newColumn - The piece's column after the move.
      newRow - The piece's row after the move.
      Returns:
      Returns a boolean value based on if the user has made a valid move.

    • getMovementLine

      public java.util.ArrayList<int[]> getMovementLine​(java.util.function.IntFunction<java.lang.Integer> rowDirection, java.util.function.IntFunction<java.lang.Integer> colDirection)
      Iterate through one possible direction, or "line", of movement, starting from the piece's origin. Keeps adding valid moves to the movement line until another piece or the edge of the board is encountered. For use with pieces with movement "speed" limit only by the board: Rook, Bishop, Queen.
      Parameters:
      rowDirection - IntFunction to represent row traversal. r -> r-- for moving left, r -> r++ for moving right.
      colDirection - IntFunction to represent column traversal. c -> c-- for moving down, c -> c++ for moving up.
      Returns:
      An ArrayList containing valid moveset coordinates. These should be combined with other directional iterations to generate the full moveset.

    • testMoves

      public java.util.ArrayList<int[]> testMoves​(java.util.ArrayList<int[]> allPossibleMoves)
      Filters a complete moveset so that only moves that do not put one's own King in check remain.
      Parameters:
      allPossibleMoves - Full moveset of a piece. Should be generated using getValidMoves().
      Returns:
      Moveset containing only valid moves that do not put the player's own King in check.

    • getValidMoves

      public abstract java.util.ArrayList<int[]> getValidMoves()
      Returns the set of valid moves available to a piece.
      Returns:
      Returns an ArrayList of coordinate pairs, each representing a valid move.
